description: From Middle English timely, tymely, timliche, from Old English *tīmlīc (adj) and tīmlīċe (“in good time; timely; soon”, adverb), equivalent to time +‎ -ly. Cognate with Danish timelig, Swedish timlig, Icelandic tímalegur, tímanlegur.

entries.meaning: Done at the proper time or within the proper time limits; prompt.
examples: Synonyms: on time, well-timed; see also Thesaurus:punctual
Antonyms: ill-timed, late; see also Thesaurus:overdue

entries.meaning: Happening or appearing at the proper time.
examples: Synonyms: opportune, seasonable; see also Thesaurus:timely
Antonyms: inopportune, unseasonable; see also Thesaurus:untimely

adverbs.description: timely (comparative more timely, superlative most timely)

examples: ‘If I had been born more timely, he said, Rhaegar would have married me instead of Elia, and it would all have come out different.’

entries.meaning: (law) In compliance with applicable time limits.
examples: On May 14, 1997, the jury convicted the defendant, who currently is serving a fifteen-month sentence. The defendant timely appeals.
